segments.text: A lot of people, big men already.
As a man asked him, about 65 or 70 years old, the other one was like 45 years old.
They were standing next to a post of the telephone.
And the big man said to the other one, he said, hey, this wire is hole, how do you speak for him?
Then the other one said to him, but how are you so dumb like that?
Don't you see that the voice runs through the electricity?
He said, well, I thought the wire was hollowed out.
Well, there's the ignorance.
It's like I say, people didn't know how to read.
Many took a piece of paper and looked at it, but they didn't know anything.
That's all that happened.
I also came to work, I earned 15 cents.
Taking care of some...
They had like a dairy here.
The becerros, you know what they are?
Beceros.
Beceros, sí.
Bueno, cuidaba yo los beceros acá, vacina a las pastas, a cuidarlos allá, y la tarde los traigo allí.
Y eso ganaba 15 centavos por día, nada más.
Pero en ese tiempo estaba todo muy barato también.
Sí.
Mucho, muy barato todo.
And now, people get sick.
A lot of people died because there were no doctors.
Yes.
In those days, Mexico was very far behind.
That's why.
And in which town do you live in Mexico?
In which town?
What's your town called?
I used to live in a very big farm that the Spaniards had.
Many years ago, when Spain ruled Mexico for a long time.
It was called...
La hacienda esa se llamaba Piautillos.
El estado de San Luis.
De San Luis corría la línea de San Luis a Tampico.
Y sobre la línea esa estaba ese lugar.
Y allí es donde mi papá allí, pues allí se crió, yo creo.
Y allí nací yo.
Y me crié hasta de 12 años.
Me vine para acá, para la frontera.
Y así estuvimos acá.
Pero, pues la gente muy pobrecita, ¿sabes?
No...
Well, there was nowhere to earn money.
There was nowhere to work.
People didn't get paid for their work.
They didn't get a good salary or anything.
That's why.
And as I say, people were missing from school so they knew something.
So they could read newspapers and find out about other places, how things were.
But without knowing anything, they couldn't know anything.
And what year did your family come here to the border?
No.
In what year?
When they killed Madero, it was in 1913.
It was when they killed Madero and the generals of Porfirio Díaz.
between Piedras Negras and Viacuña, between Egle Paz and the river.
Yes.
That's where we were.

Then he came to take a Mexican commission here to the state of Texas, because a rich man from Monterrey had land in that place, and a part of land from the government too, and he took people from here,
to plant there if they had their mules, their tools.
He took everything.
It didn't cost him anything, just the passage and the family.
And everyone went to plant there, to that place.

But in the revolution that was in Mexico, the people said that the federals, the people of the federation, the government that has been doing to the people this and that, well, many came and left, just like those who leave for the people.
They left everything.
And they didn't do anything to him.
We were there, they didn't do anything to anyone.
Yes, they kicked us out because they said that... Because a son, the man who took that place was called Lorenzo González Treviño.
And he had a son too.
And he raised people in favor of Carranza.
Yes, Carranza.
He was the one who fought against Victoriano Huerta.
And when the Federals got there, they said that even the Peruvians had to kill and burn everything.
But they didn't do anything.
Because at that time, the Federals were in Torreón.
And Francisco Villa attacked Torreón and beat them.
And they only knew that they were here in Piedras Negras and they ran to the mountains.
And they left everything.
They didn't do anything.
And that year, there were some very big harvests that happened, like no other year.
Well, but whatever it was, Mexico was very tough because, as here, God doesn't want there to be a war here.

Because if here in Brine there is a general with so many people, another Houston general comes to attack this one with twice as many people, this one doesn't wait for him, because he says, I won't resist.
They left here, and that's what they did there.
The warehouses that they had, they lit fire to them.
The people, what were they going to do afterwards?
They were fine there, the government gave them food for the soldiers and the people.
But the people?
They got very tough there.
That's why I say, I hope they don't do that here.
Because there were times when people didn't have anything to eat.
That's the truth.
It's a very hard war, wherever it is.
That's why I say that I hope that this never comes here, because many of us are going to die of hunger here if we live.
But I hope not.
That's how it happened in Mexico, and that's why I came here too.
I went to this side, looking for life, the truth, looking to work to live.

That's why I came, because it was already very hard, they couldn't invest anything, because after the parties that there were, Carranza and Huerta, then many got up and then many were not fighting, but stealing from the rich.
They became animals and everything.
I'm not talking about that I live in Carranza,
Huerta and no.
That's why we came here.
Do you want to listen to it?
It's being recorded, right?
Yes.
It's being recorded.
Your book is very good.
I write it, you listen to it, and then you write it.
I've never been to Mexico.
I haven't been to Mexico.
Yes, I know Mexico very well.
I don't know much about Mexico, the center of Mexico, the city of Mexico, because, as I say, my parents were very poor.
They barely worked to live.
They spent a lot of money to go there.
They spent a lot of money to go there.
But now... Now there are many.
Mexico is very beautiful.
What people want in Mexico is to be very kind to everyone.
There is no discrimination.
Everyone is the same.
How many years did you have when you came to the United States?
Well, all of that comes from the beginning of the world, according to what I have read.
From the beginning of the world comes all of that that many did not want to know each other.
And so, well, everything goes on.
But now, in the present, everything is peaceful, everyone is living very well.
Yes, but not in these years.
In those years, no.
In the war, no.
And ma'am, where in Mexico are you from?
I'm from Nuevo León.
Nuevo León?
In the Villa de Santiago.
Villa de Santiago.
And what year did you come to the United States?
Well, on the 19th we moved here because me and him moved to Mexico.
Oh, to Mexico.
And what town did you find?
Well, right there.
The town we found was here in Black Rocks.
When they passed us.
In which town?
In Piedras Negras.
In Piedras Negras, perhaps.
Before that, they called it Porfirio Díaz City.
Before that?
Yes, many years ago.
Ah, in what year?
That's what they called it.
Because we came from Monterrey by train to that place.
And they asked us, people on the train, where are you going?
My mother would say, let's go to Piedras Negras.
And they would say, oh, you're going to help Porfirio Díaz.
That's how they called him.
But in that time that we came, it was already in peace, but it was barely, as they say in Mexico, starting to lift everything up.
Because of the revolution, everything was destroyed.
Everything.
It was a very tough war.
Because, as I tell you, they would go, they would burn there.
They would remove a rail from the line on this side and another on this side.
Then with a chain, they would tie the end of the rail of this and this other and they would turn on the machine's chain and go, look, there is the line.
They would get to a bridge, they would put dynamite on the other side so that it would not serve the others who came.
That's why they did that.
It's a destruction of everything.
That's what I say, it's very hard.
Now, it fascinates you, just like the wars that have happened here in other places.
They destroy everything.
Well, I can't do it anymore.
First, please tell me your name.
What's your name?
Right now, I don't have many things in mind.
No, tell him your name.
My name?
Yes.
Margarito Sustaita.
And your town in Mexico was...
The town where you were born?
Yes.
I was born in a hacienda in Mexico.
And what is the name of the hacienda?
It's called Peotillos.
In what state was it?
San Luis Potosí.
And close to the town, which town?
Close to...
The closest was...
It used to be Villa Iturbide, now it's Villa Hidalgo.
I'm registered and baptized there.
It's like... and here at the school is the place.
And what year were you born?
And what year did you come to the United States?
1919, in November.
I went this way.
And what year did you leave your farm for the first time?
Where was I the first time I went?
Yes.
When I went this way, I was in B.
Wells planting onions.
From there I came to Viure.
I was sowing in agriculture.
In 1920 and in 1921.
From there I moved to another town called Yula.
It's on the way to San Marcos.
I was sowing there with a man in a ranch.
His name was Agustín Gargoyle.
I've been here for 22, 23, and 24 years.
I came here in 1924.
I came here in November, and I've been living here ever since.
In Guam.
I came here to the Boran to plant, for agriculture.
Here in Guam too?
In the Boran, yes.
I spent 14 years in the Boran, and I came here three times.
On the 27th, I moved to Alboran to sow with our Yende.
And on the 41st, I left to sow with the last one, and then I moved to Alboran.
Well, what was your father's name?
My father?
Yes.
My father's name was Rosalío Sustaita.
And your mother?
Ventura Navarro.
And did they live all their lives there in the farm?
No.
One year or two they were in that farm.
Then, because they had relatives in Monterrey, my father came and my grandmother was there on his side.
My grandmother had been dead for years.
When we came to Monterrey, we were there for a year or two.
We came back to the farm.
Y la última vez ya cuando él se vino para acá, para Texas, a las Piscas de Algodón.
Y como los parientes que estaban ahí en Monterrey, ahí estaban y él se enfermó aquí y se fue para Monterrey y de ahí nos mandó a traer de allá a Monterrey.
Y de ahí los parientes se vinieron aquí a la orilla del río, cerca de Viacuña.
¿En qué año?
In 1911, they arrived there.
And my father went there that year.
And in 1912, he sent us from there to that place there.
And there we were, when the revolution in Mexico was 13, we were already there.
And from there, I spent seven years in that place, and from there I came here.
in 1919, because the revolution left everything.
Life was very hard there.
And we came in search of work to make a living.
And here, as there was no agriculture in that place, I had to sow in agriculture too.
And that's it.
And then I left, I stopped sowing, I got a job in the dining room at the school.
I worked there for 20 years.
And then they kicked me out because of my age.
And I've always worked without a job, because I don't go to work because of my age.
I'm going to work.
How old are you?
You're 75 years old now.
No, I'm not 75.
You don't have to know.
To work, you have to work in the work you do outside.
that I can do.
And that is what is happening right now in the world.
I am receiving social security, which is what is helping me.
When you were young in Mexico, what kind of things did you do?
For example, was there work for the children?
No, very good.
He says, what were you doing there?
Were you working for the children or what?
Oh, there in the farm, as I told you the other time, I was taking care of some beceros.
Do you know what a becero is?
Yes.
It had a dairy, as they call it here.
Yes.
Very big.
You had to bring up to 50 beceros.
And that's the work I did there.
I would take them to the pasture, I would take care of them.
In the afternoon, I would take them to the corral.
I would give them pasture and I would take care of them.
And that's where I would work.
For how many years did you live in this farm?
In this farm?
Yes.
I tell you that sometimes we were there, sometimes we were in Monterrey.
Yes.
But I...
In that farm I went to school, but very few, not many.
When I learned to read and write, little to tell.
Because here with my children, my children that I was sowing, when the fishing came, they told me that I was going to weigh the cotton to all those who were fishing there.
That's what he gave me.
I gave him, on Saturday, a sheet of paper with all the names of those who were peeping, how many pounds each one had and how much money it was.
He just paid for everything.
And if someone asked him, well, you have so many pounds, how are you?
And if someone said, well, no, you're wrong.
I already told him, well, it's settled with me.
They fixed the level and his account was in the wrong.
As I said, I don't take anything from anyone.
I take everything from everyone.
At night I had a lot of work to get everyone's account.
Because I had up to 150 hands.
And I had to get everyone's account every day.
At night I had to get everyone's account.
And how much money each person earned.
That was my job here.
Yes.
Well, this is where I exercised more the... the... the numbering.
In that.
Because over there, no...
In that time in Mexico it was very... well... as I thought hours later that I was here.
From the people over there.
Very good lands.
With the water that would fall, they would raise crops.
Because the land wouldn't break down.
They would store it.
What would be sown with that water would be used for farming.
Because they would go there very often.
But there was no one... No one to open the agriculture.
As I said, people were very ignorant, they didn't know anything.
The owners of those places, no.
But what was the name of the owner of the farm?
The owner of the farm?
Yes.
His name was... His name was Morieles.
Yes.
His name was Ignacio Morieles, the owner of the farm.
He had children.
But his name was Ignacio Morieles.
He had a house...
It was almost a block away.
It was just a house.
It was a house, as they called it there.
Who knows if you've read or heard of it.
It was a house of a count.
It had a house.
It had two floors.
Below, it was just a cellar.
Outside, around.
And inside,
There were rooms like this, like this, and like this, and like this.
And in the middle, they were just gardens that were made with a fountain of water in the middle.
And inside that farm, there were many men who worked.
There was the bakery, there was the market.
For me, the farm.
And I had the work they had there.
People who occupied, men and women, to do the work there in the farmhouse.
Because there was one who was there, who was named there, administrator.
He was in charge, the owners were in San Luis.
But he was in charge there of everything.
The owners live in San Luis, in the city.
And another man is in charge of the farmhouse.
It's like here, a man has a ranch.
Well, if he doesn't want to live here, he has a man to take care of the ranch.
That's how it was there.
The house, here to the front, was long, it had many rooms and portals.
And wide, almost like from here to the street, wide the portal.
And the rooms were here to the inside.
And from there, from the portal to the outside, it was from the ground below, it was like San Otrocina.
Filled with land in pure gardens.
That they had there of flowers, plants and everything.
Very beautiful.
And on this side where the house of the hacienda ended, the pader was pure stone.
Mix, so thick, the pader.
And there was a large gate and it had an arch on the door of the hacienda.
And on the inside, they had, at that time there were no cars, they had bogies.
And they had horses to light the bogies when the one in charge of the farm wanted to go out for a walk with the family.
And they had a very big square, almost a block of barns, big.
And from the ones that went into the room over there, from there to the barn, there were like five warehouses.
Big, long.
They were like... What do they have in their mouths?
They were big.
They were stuck together.
And in that store they had a lot of... No, they don't have anything.
Maybe you don't know it or haven't seen it.
They call it lechubilla.
That's where they get the lister to make the roux.
Yes.
That's where they get it.
and palm trees.
Do you know what a palm tree is?
Well, that palm tree, the branch is so tall, the branch is long, the palm tree is very thin.
And there they make clothes too.
Well, that's what produced a lot of that place.
And from there, that's the work they had in those warehouses.
And they made, well, some big, so tall, round, so tall.
And they would board to San Luis where they would ask for train vans full of... And they would board to San Luis where they would ask for them.
And from there, the church that was there would continue.
The church was very big, full of stone, full of concrete.
And the farm.
And over there, there were the rooms of those who worked there,
The secretaries and everything.
And then there was the school for women and the school for men.
That's where I went to school.
For all the children in the hacienda?
They were like this, they came to Callasina.
Well, they made a corner here.
They were in this and here, and we were in this and here.
And then there was a very big warehouse, very big, that had a lot of things in there.
And I only came to study, I started number three.
Yes.
But when it was like, I don't know here, they went as inspectors, who are going to see how high one is in reading.
There were books that I had to study.
And the teacher would take the book, and I would tell him everything.
I would give it to him.
And the reading books, to read.
And then the arithmetic, the numbers, to do the math and all that.
And that year, of all those who were there,
I did all the things that the Lord told me to do.
And they said it was enough.
But it wasn't enough because it was a school like in a city that studies a lot.
Like my children, they studied in the ranch there.
It's not that the ranch is not the same here in the town.
It's very different because here they learn more.
And that's why they learned, but it wasn't enough.
And that's what happened.
And what kind of work did your father have in this farm?
Well, for his work, it was... That same farm had chickens.
And since it was very big, I think, who knows if it would reach more than just the land it had.
Chickens?
Yes, from that farm.
It's like wagons, you know?
Oh, yes.
It's like wagons.
It's like wagons.
It's like wagons.
It's like wagons.
It's like wagons.
It's like wagons.
Some earned money from other farms that were here, and others earned money from other farms that were here.
And they brought the same thing to make the rice.
That's what they brought.
They brought goods for the people from there.
And from here they came in loaded with this, which they call istle.
Yes.
From here is what they brought.
That's why the warehouses they had there were full of that material.
When they sent an order, a big order, they had two tramways stretched out by mules.
Because the depot of the train that passed, I think it was like Vieja del Colegio.
They had two tramways, platforms, and they loaded everything with the mules stretched out for them.
And the people would carry them on the train.
And they would come back empty-handed to take more, until they filled it all up.
And that was the work they had to do.
And your mother, did she have a job too?
No, she didn't work in that place.
No, she didn't get to work.
She did work here on the outside, like any other sewing that they could do.
What kind of house did your family have in the farm?
What kind of houses?
Yes, for their families.
Do you know that this farm was formed with a village?
Yes.
And it was big, with many houses.
Everyone had, like here, like here I am, I have here my yard and everything.
Here they had those houses.
But no one paid a penny.
No?
No.
They didn't pay rent, they didn't pay taxation, they didn't pay anything.
They were living there.
All the people.
That's what they had.
And they had a right side and a left side.
And then they crossed the street.
In the form of a town.
What kind of material was there?
There were houses that were made there.
And here I have seen two houses that are called adobe.
Yes.
Well, that's how the houses were made.
Yes.
There, adobe.
It's not that...
The Adobo is so wide.
In the Revolution, the Adobo's bullets didn't go through.
Because it's so wide, that's how you can see it.
And so long, that's how you can see it.
There's a lot of defense for the people there.
Well, what kind of things happened in this area during the first years of the Revolution?
The first years?
Yes.
In 1910, 1911, 1912, what kind of things happened in the hacienda?
Soldiers or other problems?
I didn't understand the people very well.
What kind of work did they do?
Or what things did they do?
Well, tell me about the life in the farm during the first years of the revolution.
Tell me about these things.
The people, the farm had a lot of land.
Yes.
Now, outside the houses, it was already called here, pastas.
He had a lot of maguey.
Do you know maguey?
Yes.
I have here three very big ones.
Well, the maguey, the people went to the pastas and it was almost even.
It was maguey and nopal.
In Mexico tuna is given a lot.
Cardona.
That tuna is...
They do a lot of things with it.
Yes.
And there are tuna cheeses that they call it.
There's honey that they call tuna.
Others call it, it's a little thicker, they give it another name.
And from the tuna seeds, they fatten the browns.
They fatten the browns with the tuna seeds.
And a lot of people were going to be named there to break a maguey.
That's to get water and honey from the maguey.
Maguey water is very healthy, very healthy, better than coffee.
Well, people would go in the morning, they would bring the honey, big buckets or whatever they could, and they would bring it home.
In the morning and in the afternoon.
And where they made holes in the maguey like this,
Everything that was down there, from the head of the maguey up there, gave the honey.

Well, they put a stone in the cover, in the hole, so that the coyotes or other animals, and if the coyote tried to remove the stone, they would put it, there's a lot, a kind of thorn that they call it there, coconoste, it's very thorny.
Yes.
That's the cane, it's thin, but it has a lot of thorns.
It's thin, but it has a lot of thorns, very big thorns.
And that's what they put on it so that the coyote doesn't get hurt.
And in the month of June, you saw the paste that looked like a stick.
It was the kiyote that they made.
Yes.
You see that many people went to the paste, cut the kiyote,
with a lot of dry straw, dry marguerite, and I made a fire and I put it in the fire.

I took it to the house, I made a well in the ground, I threw a lot of firewood, I threw stones down, and then I had a lot of firewood down, I put the firewood inside and then I covered it up and I threw firewood.
The next day it was well cooked and very sweet.
Well, that farm had a lot of
Many things had a tree that they called garambullo.
That one throws the fruit like the grape.
At the end of May it is blooming, you can only see the white flowers.
And by the end of June it is already ripe.
That is the garambullo.
And in the month of August, the nopalera, that you can only see it colored, all that is pure tuna.
And people grab a piece like that and make it, because the store sells them.
It's not very expensive, right?
It's not very expensive.
And everyone grabs a piece like that and goes to cut the tuna with a, they make a
A piece of board or any piece of stick.
They put a knife on top of it.
You see that the crown of the tuna, the fin of the tuna, they give it like this, just that everything is not cut.
And then with the same knife they cut it down.
And there are people who are working.
They named it there, peeling the tuna and taking out the pure tuna and putting it in baskets.
And they take it to work.
That's the work that exists.
It's that in the month of August there's a lot of that there.
A lot.
And the hacienda there had a garden, like that, of the house of the hacienda, like that, a garden.
Here they had everything.
Trees, fruits and iron.
They had vegetables and everything.
That was to support the house and the farm.
It was very peaceful.
People were used to it.
They were used to it.
Like here, we are used to living like this.
People were the same.
Living well.
But no one paid anything.
No, they didn't pay anything.
What did they pay?
Income?
Transactions?
No.
They all had their own places.
Many had a store to sell something.
Some made shoes.
Others were sastres.
Do you know what sastres are?
Women were also sastres.
Some were fashionistas, dressed like the people of Margenza.
They tried to make a living.
That was what they did.
But the work was the same.
Many who didn't work in the hacienda
They sowed, there were places where the soil was clean.
There they sowed everything.
Because there, in that place, it's not very hot, nor is it very cold.
It's just like that.
What height was it?
What height?
At what height?
Well, it's not very cold and it's not very hot.
It's in the mountains, right?
Because here it's very hot.
Yes.
And it's very cold.
Yes.
Well, I didn't know the snow that they said, like here.
Yes.
There, I heard that they said...
It snowed in the mountains, but I never saw it there.
Not even the cold air from the north.
Until I came here to the border, to the banks of the Rio Grande, there in Miacuña and Piedra Nera, there I came to see the north.
It wasn't cold there.
In the morning, just like in that time, it was just scorching.
And it was like ice in the night, that dawns whitening.
That was all there was.
But there was no cold air.
It was beautiful.
The plants don't wash because they freeze hard, like here.
Here in the north it's cold and it burns things.
If it was cold like here, there wouldn't be that kind of plants in the pastas.
Maguey doesn't freeze.
Nor does nopal.
But there are other plants that do freeze.
And that's what was there.
And a lot of people plant outside.
They have a lot of land.
They plant everything there in the work they do.
They plant corn.
Between the corn, they planted beans.
They planted pumpkin.
Do you know what that is?
Yes.
Well, there's another plant that they call corn from Teja.
It's a big wheel.
Corn from Texas?
Corn from Texas, they call it.
It's bigger.
They plant it here and it grows, and here they plant it like this.
And those grains are filled with those little balls.
Yes.
Well, all this was given between corn, and here it's not given.
Here it burns.
The same heat of the corn doesn't let it dry.
And that's how it is.
When the corn is dry, they cut it.
And they do it a lot.
And then you see the land that looks like the land of so many pumpkins.
Of all of them.
It's for the same people.
They use it for many things.
Now the beans are the same as the corn.
Because there in Mexico, years have passed and I don't know how it will be now.
Because since I came from there, from Hacienda Piotrillo, from 2012, I haven't gone back there.
It was in 1912.
1912 that I came here to the river, to the border here.
To the border.
What were you doing?
Why did you go to the border?
Because my father is here, in this place, in the middle of Piedras Negras and Viacuña.
And he brought them from there, so we could come to where he was.
And that's why we came from there.
That's why I tell you that he didn't... And what kind of work did he have on the border?
Here, agriculture.
Agriculture, too.
In that place... Because that man...
He was from Monterrey.
He had a lot of land between Piedaneras and Viacuña.
And he sent a man to come here to Texas to talk to the Mexicans who were sowing here.
And I told them, well, I was coming here to the house.
And as I was coming here, he said, well, say hello.
Well, you are sowing here.
